title: VIP: Add abi.decode
body:
## Simple Summary
Add `abi.decode` to Vyper similar to what is implemented in https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/pull/4390

## Abstract
Encoding is hard! It seems that abi encoding is a solid encoding format--likely better than RLP. SSZ encoding is being used in Eth2.0 and apparently it is quite similar to ABI encoding which is a good signal. Would be great to have Vyper support.

## Motivation
There are a number of teams (including Plasma Group) which need ABI encoding and this is actually a huge blocker with implementing our smart contracts in Vyper.

## Specification
See the Python implementation here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth-abi
See the Solidity PR here: https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/pull/4390
There are some docs here: https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.5.3/abi-spec.htm

## Backwards Compatibility
This is a new feature.

## Dependencies
Not that I am aware of.

## Copyright
Copyright and related rights waived via [CC0](https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/)

@karlfloersch I'm curious what the use case is for using `abi.decode` rather than just passing in data as arguments to functions? (Note that ABI encode/decode is already the standard for how function arguments are decoded from tx data).

@charles-cooper many token extensions (as well as other methodologies) allow passing unstructured data through as an argument to a destination call address for further parsing. For example, ERC-777 `function send(address to, uint256 amount, bytes calldata data)`. This allows unstructured data to by parsed by smart contracts on the receive side of a transfer, and `abi.decode` allows them to interpret that data in a specific way on the receive side e.g. a transaction struct or something like that.
@fubuloubu gotcha. I think the trickiest part about this spec is for the typechecker to dynamically deduce a type. But I suppose it could just have the same signature as `RLPList`, `bytes -> *`.
In general, `abi.decode(bytes[N], [typ1, typ2, ...]) -> (typ1, typ2, ...)` where `N` has to be long enough to encode `typ1, typ2, ...`
`abi.encode(typ1, typ2, ...) -> bytes[N]` is even easier, we can derive the types of the inputs
Maybe an an alternative might be to leverage kwargs for `abi.decode` a la `abi.decode(bytes, encoding=(typ1, typ2, ...))`, but I'm on the fence about that
I think you can even avoid using `abi.decode(TYPE, bytes_)` and go with `abi.decode(bytes_)` because in general the LHS is already known.

Oh yeah! Duh!

I remember talking about this before... many issues ago...

> @fubuloubu gotcha. I think the trickiest part about this spec is for the typechecker to dynamically deduce a type. But I suppose it could just have the same signature as `RLPList`, `bytes -> *`.

+1 for using RLPList style notation.
@fubuloubu I'm definitely in over my head here, but I'll take this issue :)

@skellet0r this may not be as much work as you'd think, the idea we had was to leverage our internal ABI decoder and make it available as a feature. That might probe difficult in and of itself, but you dont have to implement everything ftom scratch!

lol SWEEET thxs @fubuloubu
Definitely not in over my head now

> lol SWEEET thxs @fubuloubu
> Definitely not in over my head now

haha, yes!

To explain a little further, the thinking was that this would be how it would work:

```python
from ethereum.abi import decode as abi_decode  # Just to namespace this method
# data: Bytes[96]
a, _, b = abi_decode("uint256,uint256,uint256", data)
# Maybe also use it like `abi.decode(...)`
```

This is maybe another way it could be done: https://github.com/vyperlang/vyper/issues/1406#issuecomment-487425855

I think having the types at the end could be nice because it makes it possible for that to be a kwarg instead (when not specified, have it derive automatically from the expected output types)

Yeah I definitely like that syntax more with the kwarg usage
```python
abi.decode(data, types=[uint256, uint256, address, ...])
```

Question though, if we derive from the LHS, would that mean the following syntax is supported:

```python
a: uint256, b: uint256 ... = abi.decode(data)
```

Or would we still require zero initializing variables with their specified type before the decode usage? (I would prefer this since it's explicit)

```python
a: uint256 = 0
...
a, b, c = abi.decode(data)
```

> Question though, if we derive from the LHS, would that mean the following syntax is supported:

Python doesn't support this now, but I could see adding this in the future with a custom parser

> Or would we still require zero initializing variables with their specified type before the decode usage? (I would prefer this since it's explicit)

We'd have to do this for now though
I'm not a fan of deriving the output type(s) by looking at the LHS, as it creates a situation where the outcome of an expression is dependent upon how it is observed.  This feels backward to me.

> Yeah I definitely like that syntax more with the kwarg usage
> 
> ```python
> abi.decode(data, types=[uint256, uint256, address, ...])
> ```

Yeah I'd say start with this approach
Resolved in #2401
Hi guys! Could you tell me when approximately the release date for this feature? It would be great to use decoding inside the Vyper instead of writing helper contracts on Solidity!
My bad for closing this issue, we added support for `abi_encode` but not `abi_decode` (yet)
@charles-cooper is it something you could help with? Do you know if that's in progress? or there are any workarounds to decode abi with current vyper version?

@adapt7 I had put this on the back burner since mostly people were asking for `abi.encode` (which is now implemented).

I can add this, but note that you can also decode bytestrings "by hand" using `convert` and `slice`. For instance, if you wanted to decode `b: Bytes[32]` which encodes `(uint256)`, you could use `convert(slice(b, 0, 32), uint256)`. Decoding bytestrings would be more complicated. If you get in touch on our discord I can walk you through your specific case.

@charles-cooper many thanks. Will that also work for decoding addresses? Let's say I generate `b: Bytes[64] = abi.encode(address, address)`. To decode it will that be as simple as `convert(slice(b, 0, 32), address)` and `convert(slice(b, 32, 64), address)`?
@adapt7 Yes!
closed in https://github.com/vyperlang/vyper/pull/2882
